event.name: From Bits to Beings: Deconstructing Information
event.description: A deep dive into the fundamental concept of information as it appears in physics, biology, and human language. Is information physical? Can it be destroyed?
event.dynamics: Each of the three panelists will give a 15-minute presentation on 'information' from their field's perspective. This will be followed by a 45-minute moderated debate and audience discussion.

participants.name: Dr. Fatima Al-Jamil
participants.bio: Associate Professor of Computer Science at MIT. Her research in Human-Computer Interaction often grapples with the 'semantic gap'â€”the difference between machine data and human meaning.

participants.name: Dr. Leo Vance
participants.bio: A theoretical physicist from the Perimeter Institute, renowned for his work on the black hole information paradox and the connections between quantum mechanics and information theory.

participants.name: Dr. Isabella Rossi
participants.bio: Neuroscientist from the Max Planck Institute. Dr. Rossi's lab focuses on neural coding, investigating how patterns of neuron firing encode sensory information from the outside world.

participants.name: Dr. Samuel Chen
participants.bio: A historical linguist from the University of Oxford. His book, 'The Symbol's Legacy,' traces the evolution of writing systems as technologies for preserving information across millennia.

roles.name: Moderator
roles.description: Introduces the speakers, manages presentation times, and guides the post-presentation debate.

roles.name: Panelist
roles.description: Presents a focused talk on the topic and engages in debate with other experts.
